dublin_core.dcvalue: Close, E. W., Conn, J., & Close, H. G. (2014). Development of Integrated Physics Identity through Physics Learning Assistant Experience. In Joseph L. Polman, Eleni A. Kyza, D. Kevin O'Neill, Iris Tabak, William R. Penuel, A. Susan Jurow, Kevin O'Connor, Tiffany Lee, and Laura D'Amico (Eds.). Learning and Becoming in Practice: The International Conference of the Learning Sciences (ICLS) 2014. Volume 3. Colorado, CO: International Society of the Learning Sciences, pp. 1533-1534.

We propose that connections between persistence, career trajectory, and participation in a Physics Learning Assistant (LA) program can be explained using the concept of the community of practice and its intimate relationship to identity. Preliminary analysis of written artifacts and interviews suggests that membership in the collaborative physics education community of practice created through the LA program increases LAs' engagement in negotiation of meaning in both instructor and student roles and strengthens their physics identity.
Boulder, CO: International Society of the Learning Sciences
Development of Integrated Physics Identity through Physics Learning Assistant Experience
